Convergence and Heterogeneity. 
We evaluate the convergence rate, training time, and accuracy of Upcycled-FL under different parameter settings. We take λm=λ,∀msubscript𝜆𝑚𝜆for-all𝑚\lambda_{m}=\lambda,\forall m in experiments, while we observe similar results for time-varying λmsubscript𝜆𝑚\lambda_{m}. Table 1 compares the training/testing accuracy of different algorithms when the device heterogeneity is high (90% stragglers). The results show that Upcycled-FL outperforms both FedProx and FedAvg on all datasets (with appropriate μ𝜇\mu). While FedAvg achieves good performance on Synthetic(iid), it is not robust to heterogeneous data. When data is i.i.d., adding the proximal term μ2​‖ω−ω¯t‖2𝜇2superscriptnorm𝜔superscript¯𝜔𝑡2\frac{\mu}{2}||\omega-\overline{\omega}^{t}||^{2} may hurt the performance. However, the proximal term can help stabilize the algorithm and significantly improve the performance in practical settings when data is heterogeneous; these observations are consistent with [2]. Importantly, Upcycled-FL is more robust to the level of statistical heterogeneity than FedProx as it could attain consistent improvements for all settings. In practice, μ𝜇\mu needs to be carefully tuned; with a carefully selected μ𝜇\mu, Upcycled-FL could achieve 2%∼7%similar-topercent2percent72\%\sim 7\% improvement on accuracy compared to FedProx.

Convergence and Heterogeneity. 
We evaluate the convergence rate, training time, and accuracy of Upcycled-FL under different parameter settings. We take λm=λ,∀msubscript𝜆𝑚𝜆for-all𝑚\lambda_{m}=\lambda,\forall m in experiments, while we observe similar results for time-varying λmsubscript𝜆𝑚\lambda_{m}. Table 1 compares the training/testing accuracy of different algorithms when the device heterogeneity is high (90% stragglers). The results show that Upcycled-FL outperforms both FedProx and FedAvg on all datasets (with appropriate μ𝜇\mu). While FedAvg achieves good performance on Synthetic(iid), it is not robust to heterogeneous data. When data is i.i.d., adding the proximal term μ2​‖ω−ω¯t‖2𝜇2superscriptnorm𝜔superscript¯𝜔𝑡2\frac{\mu}{2}||\omega-\overline{\omega}^{t}||^{2} may hurt the performance. However, the proximal term can help stabilize the algorithm and significantly improve the performance in practical settings when data is heterogeneous; these observations are consistent with [2]. Importantly, Upcycled-FL is more robust to the level of statistical heterogeneity than FedProx as it could attain consistent improvements for all settings. In practice, μ𝜇\mu needs to be carefully tuned; with a carefully selected μ𝜇\mu, Upcycled-FL could achieve 2%∼7%similar-topercent2percent72\%\sim 7\% improvement on accuracy compared to FedProx.

Figure 3(a) and 3(b) demonstrate the performance (averaged loss and the respective privacy loss ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon) of (non-)private Upcylced-FL and private FedProx on synthetic data using objective perturbation.
As expected, private Upcycled-FL is much more stable and significantly improves both privacy and accuracy over private FedProx. This is because the private Upcycled-FL with less information leakage requires much less perturbation to attain the same privacy guarantee as private FedProx. In general, we observe that private Upcycled-FL can experience 9.5% less privacy loss than private FedProx, and meanwhile having 11.0% (or 11.5%) higher training (or testing) accuracy on average and reducing 48% of training time. We also conduct similar experiments using output perturbation (Figure 3(c) and 3(d)). Results show that on average, private
Upcycled-FL can experience 12.0% less privacy loss than private FedProx while having 6.1% (or 6.2%) higher training (or testing) accuracy; the training time is still reduced by 48% under Upcycled-FL.
A brief summary of dataset can be found in Table 2.
